Name: Banana
Question: Monkeys peel their bananas upside-down compared to humans
Fact: The banana made its name after it was sold wrapped in aluminum foil for 10 cents in the 1876 Philadelphia World Fair.

Name: Blackcurrant
Question: Leaves of blackcurrant are used as flavoring agents for producing some Vodka in Russia
Fact: Blackcurrant is used to make jams, jellies and syrups and is grown commercially for the juice market.

Name: Blueberry
Question: The bell-shaped flowers of blueberries are blue
Fact: Humans are thought to have been eating blueberries for over 10,000 years.

Name: Chili pepper
Question: The Scoville Heat Unit (SHU) is the measure to quantify how spicy a pepper is
Fact: The Carolina Reaper is the world's hostest chilli (2020).

Name: Cranberry
Question: Cranberries are harvested in summer
Fact: Cranberry sauce is traditionally served with turkey during Thanksgiving in the US and Canada and in the UK for Christmas.

Name: Eggplant
Question: Eggplants belong to the same plant family as potatoes, tomatoes and chilli peppers
Fact: Eggplants are thought to originate from India or Africa

Name: Gooseberry
Question: Gooseberries are a rich source of vitamin C
Fact: Gooseberry bushes are a host plant for magpie moths and comma butterflies

Name: Grape
Question: Yeast naturally occurs in the skin of grapes
Fact: Armenia is home to the earliest known winery at around 4000BC

Name: Guava
Question: Guavas are a citrus fruit
Fact: India is the biggest producer of guavas in the world

Name: Kiwifruit
Question: The whole skin of kiwis is suitable for people to eat, despiet its fuzziness
Fact: In New Zealand, kiwifruit are marketed under the brand name Zespri

Name: Lucuma
Question: Lucuma has a custard-like flavour
Fact: In Peru, Lucuma is the most popular flavour for ice cream and has been known as 'Gold of the Incas'.

Name: Pomegranate
Question: The ancient Egyptians regarded the pomegranate as a symbol of fertility
Fact: In a classical Greek myth, Persephone, daughter of Demeter, Goddess of the Harvest, is fed pomegranate seeds by Hades and is doomed to spend a fixed number of months in the underworld every year.

Name: Redcurrant
Question: Redcurrants share the same plant family as gooseberries
Fact: In France, redcurrants can be used to make Lorraine jelly.
Fruit image reference: Image by S. Hermann & F. Richter from Pixabay

Name: Tomato
Question: Botanically, tomatoes are fruit, but are recognised as culinary vegetables when it comes to cooking
Fact: Tomatoes are indigenous to S. America and central America

Name: Cucumber
Question: Cucumbers have just 50% water
Fact: Not all cucumbers cultivars require polination in order to fruit

Name: Melon
Question: Melons and cucumbers are part of the same plant family
Fact: China is the biggest producer of melons on the world

Name: Pumpkin
Question: Pumpkin pie is a traditional Thanksgiving meal in the US and Canada
Fact: Pumpkin originates from the Greek word 'pepon' which describes something large and round.

Name: Grapefruit
Question: Vietnam is the largest producer of grapefruit
Fact: Grapefruits is known of one of the "7 wonders of Barbados"

Name: Lemon
Question: India is the largest producer of lemons
Fact: Christopher Columbus introduced lemons to the Americas in the late 15th century

Name: Lime
Question: Limes are rich in vitamin C
Fact: In the 19th Century, British sailors became known as limeys, as they consumed these to prevent scurvy, a disease derived from a lack of vitamin C.

Name: Orange
Question: Oranges originate from the mediterranean
Fact: The sweet oranges we know today result from hybridising pomelos and mandarins

Name: Blackberry
Question: Chile is the largest producer of blackberries
Fact: Mexico is the biggest producer of blackberries in the world

Name: Raspberry
Question: Raspberries and Mulberries are part of the same plant family
Fact: Russia is the biggest producer of raspberries in the world
Fruit image reference: Image by S. Hermann & F. Richter from Pixabay

Name: Fig
Question: Female wasps can pollinate female figs when they climb inside
Fact: Female wasps can become trapped in figs and lay their eggs within these
Fruit image reference: Image by Thanks for your Like • donations welcome from Pixabay

Name: Mulberry
Question: Mulberries belong to the Rosaceae plant family
Fact: Mulberry trees are known to grown to 80ft in height

Name: Pineapple
Question: Pineapples are indigenous to S. America
Fact: Wild pineapples are polinated by hummingbirds

Name: Apple
Question: The flowers, precurcory to producing apples, have 6 petals
Fact: As one of his 12 labours, the mythical Greek hero, Heracles, picked golden apples from the Tree of Life in the Garden of the Hesperides.

Name: Rose hip
Question: Rose hips are not prodcued from roses
Fact: Rosehips from roses can be used to make herbal teas, jellies and marmalades

Name: Apricot
Question: Apricots are the national fruit of Armenia
Fact: Turkey is the biggest producer of apricots in the world

Name: Strawberry
Question: The seeds on the inside of a strawberry are called achenes
Fact: The seeds on the outside of strawberries are called achenes
